No, I meant following the earlier example sent by Lauren Ko.

That example set up a sheet overlay for the bean-path 
'metadata.robotsPolicyName', making it 'ignore' for some SURT prefixes.

Instead, you could set up an overlay for the bean-path 
'preconditions.calculateRobotsOnly', making it 'true' from some SURT 
prefixes.

The XML fragment you provided wouldn't do anything and would probably be 
rejected by the Spring XML-configuration reader ï¿½ a <property> can have 
an attribute 'value' or a interior element, but not both. Also, the 
'overlay sheets' mechanism collects sets of alternate settings, and the 
association of those settings to certain URI subsets, *away* from the 
main/default bean declarations. There's no mixing of alternate values or 
lists of URIs/patterns/prefixes inside the main bean declaration.

Hope this helps,

- Gordon

> <bean id="preconditions"
> class="org.archive.crawler.prefetch.PreconditionEnforcer">
> <property name="calculateRobotsOnly" value="true">
> <list>
